awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Interdisciplinary Water Science and Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
This three year renewal of a Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site Program, Interdisciplinary Water Science and Engineering, at Virginia Tech, offers an interdisciplinary research experience to a diverse cohort of students on projects leading to sustainable management of water resources in an interdisciplinary environment. New features of this renewal program include an international component in India and collaboration of some of the REU scholars with VT RET Site participants. The Site will expand the pool of future researchers in water science who will address one of the National Academy of Engineering (NAE) Grand Challenges, (i.e. provide access to clean water).    

VT will host 10 REU scholars over a 10-week summer program where they will be provided with a high-quality learning environment that: 1) stimulates their scientific curiosity in interdisciplinary water research and motivates them to pursue advanced degrees in water sciences and engineering; 2) trains them to communicate scientific information through research papers, seminars, and presentations; and 3) facilitates their social, intellectual, and professional growth. Twelve faculty mentors from diverse academic disciplines will direct REU scholars research.

por.por_cntn:
This NFS-REU site on interdisciplinary water science and engineering at Virginia Tech began in Summer 2017 and ended in late 2021. A total of 39 undergraduate students completed the program from 29 different institutions across the United States. The REU scholars received training and mentorship from a total of 14 different faculty members. The disciplinary areas of faculty members included Civil and Environmental Engineering, Engineering Education, Geosciences, Biological Sciences, Forest Resources and Environmental Conservation, and Plant Environmental Sciences. 

* Students engaged in a wide variety of research projects that included the following:

* Metal Oxidation in a Drinking Water Reservoirs

 * Drinking Water Quality Tastes and Odors

* Effects of Hydrology on Ecosystem Processes and Water Quality of Streams and Rivers

* Hydrologic Controls on Wetland Function at the Great Dismal Swamp
Recovery of Nutrients and Water from Wastewater Using an Integrated Osmotic Bio-electrochemical System

 
* Extension of Online Watershed Learning System for Remote Access of High Frequency Environmental Data and Hydrologic Analysis


* Investigation of the occurrence and fate of pharmaceuticals and personal care products (PPCPs) in urban-impacted watersheds

* Water Conservation and Waterborne Disease Nexus of Faucets


* Citizen Science Applications of the LEWAS Lab

Among the significant achievements of REU scholars in the last annual cycle, three students joined the Ph.D. program in the Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering at Virginia Tech.
